utterance.content: Uh, why?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I've been made. House sent me back to you as a double agent.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Anything wrong?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Eyes are a little red.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: There's a shocker. I haven't had a good night's sleep since this thing started. You should get some rest yourself.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: That's a good idea. This is going to take some time. It'll be pretty exhausting.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Are you afraid of what you might say while I'm here?

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Are you telling me there's something worse than what I've already heard?

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: No, I — I don't know what I'm gonna say. I don't know how I'm gonna hurt you next. I think we should be around each other as little as possible right now.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: This is pathetic.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: I know. Tell Marika I love her very much.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: She understands that.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: I don't think she does. You're just saying that to make me feel better.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Guy leads a boring life. They stay home a lot. No travel, no exotic pets, no nearby standing water.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sound pleased about something. Can we get to that part?

utterance.speaker: Kunter
utterance.content: His wife rescues dogs. Among others, a big rottweiler who's taken over the house. Our patient hates it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Was the wife there to hear this?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Too bad. Keep going.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: The dog marks his territory all over the living room. I asked what the odds were that he would have put down food or drink where the dog could reach. He said he put a glass of juice on the floor while he was fixing the television.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The dog was fixing the television?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The patient's eyes red?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Yeah. I'm thinking Weil's.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bacterial. He lucked out. Start him on doxycycline. If he improves, we'll know we were right.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I told Wilson you sent me to get information.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And now you're telling me. What does that make you, a quadruple agent?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He let me print out his e-mails.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow. Excellent. Information he wants us to have. Did he let you print out his deleted e-mails?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then go back there —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: As long as I was sitting there, I thought I'd print 'em anyway. Top one's the one you're looking for.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Writing to confirm Wednesday at 7:00 PM.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's out going to jgonzalez@nymercy.net. There's a Joan Gonzalez in oncology. It's a consult.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Secret consult, 7:00 PM. Oh, Joan is perky.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You're wrong. There was a patient file attached.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It was password-protected.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Wilson doesn't password-protect his patient files. I'm the only one he'd expect ever to look there, and he knows there's only one patient I'd want to check on.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You think Wilson’s sick?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If Wilson had cancer, there'd be no reason for him to drive three hours to Manhattan. He could pull strings here and get the best treatment. Six articles by Gonzalez. "Managing suicidal thoughts in oncology patients," "Suicidal ideation in children with leukemia."

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I don't want to ask this, but, have you ever had reason to think he might be depressed?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Get out of here.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Your fever's down and your lungs are clearing.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: How long before this brain thing goes away?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The infection's gone, but the damage the infection did; you'll have to live with.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: You're telling me you can't fix this? There's, there’s gotta be a way.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We'd need to remove the damaged area in your cingulate gyrus, but it's too close to the brainstem to risk surgery.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The brain stem controls the body's involuntary systems. The slightest mistake could kill you. Even if you survive, you may never be able to breathe on your own again. You may never—

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: I get it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I know this seems like a lot to deal with right now. But people have adapted to living with all kinds of neurological deficits.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Hey, at least we can promise you it won't get any worse.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Get the hell out of my room.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your assistant said that you were out of the hospital, taking a walk.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is there an emergency?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't know. Is there? You never take a walk unless you've got something you need to think about.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe you just don't have a good statistical sampling of my walks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The other thing you do when you need to think is you come to my office. Apparently, this is something you can only discuss with Gonzalez at New York Mercy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Taub. another graduate of the House school of being a dick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Private dick.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Look, I'd love to stay for the full inquisition, but I need some hot coffee.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course you need hot coffee. It's 45 degrees outside, and you left your coat upstairs. Why?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're going to tell me why I forgot my coat?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Once you get outside, the cold would have reminded you. You could have come back, but you didn't. You chose to be uncomfortable. Now, why would someone choose that? Because they hate themselves?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Has it ever occurred to you that when I don't share something, it might not be meant as a challenge? It might just mean that I'd like there to be one molecule of my life that goes unexamined by Gregory House.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Nick Greenwald. I hear you're the guy in charge. I'm the patient with the disinhibition.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you're here to say thanks, you're welcome. Now go away.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Oh, I'm not thankful. I'm pissed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, all the more reason to go away.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: They're talking about sending me home. To what? A life where I'll continually drive away anyone who might for a second care about me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Those are the breaks.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: You could operate.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You could die.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: So I'm either better or dead? I'm okay with that. I — I've always been kind of a… an impatient guy. But I've worked hard to keep my mouth shut. I've made my wife happy. I've made my little girl happy. I want that back. Otherwise, it's no life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want you to remove a small problem.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'm not a neurosurgeon.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But your boss is. You could assist. I'm sure you'd like to add to your resume.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's too near the brain stem. Nobody's gonna touch it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your boss would. He's an egomaniac. I know 'cause I keep seeing him at the club. He just needs a little push. I'm sure by now you've kissed his ass sufficiently. Would you like me to phrase it as "you're politically gifted"? I can do that.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You want me to help you? Tell me why.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why what?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why you care. The puzzle's solved. The guy's alive. And the odds of coming out of this surgery with that same status aren't that great.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My patient has a quality of life issue.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He says awful things, hardly a medical condition.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When he leaves here, he's going to lose his family. He's gonna alienate the people he works with. And if he ever finds a friend who's willing to put up with his crap, he'll be lucky. Until he drives them away too.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'll see what I can do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You've apparently got this whole coat thing backwards.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I may have overreacted.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You definitely overreacted.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I knew you'd meet me halfway.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It made me think. You only snap on one subject: losing people. So I went back to the intel. It's true there's only one doctor named Gonzalez at New York Mercy, but there's a Javier Gonzalez who's a nurse in the psych ward. And who could you lose who'd end up there?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe the reason I don't always open up to you is because it's redundant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Daniel Wilson. Once you got a name, it's amazing how much stuff you can learn on the phone. I mean, if you're a doctor and you lie freely. They found your brother sleeping in the lobby of an office building in Manhattan. Got aggressive when they asked him to leave, and the cops took him to the Mercy psych ward.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: There have been new anti-psychotics developed since he ran away. He's been on them for a couple of days, and by tonight, he should be in shape to talk to me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you're not sure if he wants to.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'll be in New York in a few hours, and I guess I'll find out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why wouldn't you tell me this?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, you and I… We don't have the normal social contract. I don't expect you to tell me the lies —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am fully capable of lying to you. I've lied plenty of times.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I mean, collaborative lies. Giving someone a hand who maybe needs to deceive themselves, just a little. For two days I've been thinking about how Danny’s gonna react when he sees me. If I said that to anybody else, they'd say, "don't worry, it’ll all be all right." You wouldn't.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because it might all go horribly wrong.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. Yeah, it might.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In which case, you might want some company.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your heart's beating. First hurdle passed. Now we need know if you can breathe for yourself.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Oh, thank God.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Now, do you know who you are?

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Nick Greenwald. Former SOB. Thank you. Now I can go back to my beautiful life with my beautiful wife. Maybe she'll stop whining and cut me some slack now that I've risked my life.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Doesn't make sense. We removed the problem.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We removed the damage. Maybe we were wrong about the problem.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: I need to believe we can get through this.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Temperature's 94.5

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Do you really think I'm stupid?

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Honey, you're not stupid. You're just — please don't do this.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It could be the effect of the surgery.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Do you at least respect me, Nick, what do you think of what I do for a living?

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: I think people who publicize important things are people who can't do important things themselves. Honey, stop. Don't.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Do you regret marrying me?

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Sometimes. Everybody wonders —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Get me a heating blanket.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Do you even love me?

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: I don't know why.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Audrey, wait. Let me —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: V-tach. Get me the paddles. Clear.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Echo says his heart is structurally fine, but his temperature is still dropping. He's headed for hypothermia.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I can't reach House. It just goes to voicemail.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It means we were wrong about infection. His temperature's just going up and down because something's playing with his thermostat.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Which means the brain damage is spreading.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What causes brain damage and nosebleed and involves the lungs, heart and kidneys?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Cancer? We could text him.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's not cancer. Normal PSA, normal blood smear, colonoscopy normal. Do a full body scan.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: House hates full body scans.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House isn't here.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: House is right. Everybody's got three or four meaningless anomalies that'll come up on a scan. Chasing each one will take time we don't have.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Feel free to send him an IM.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You told me you saw your brother once. After he disappeared.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: 13 years ago. I used to go to Princeton whenever I could. I must have hit every homeless shelter in town. And then one day, I’m just sitting at this deli, having a sandwich, I look out the window, and there he is. He was gone by the time I got outside.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's why you were so eager when I told you there was a job at Princeton. I thought it was just my charm.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That's the team. Shouldn't you answer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They already texted me to say they're doing something stupid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's a small abdominal aneurysm.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Irrelevant. What else you got?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Cyst in the pleura around the lungs.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Also irrelevant. Couldn't cause any of the symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's a density in the liver. Could be a vascular malformation.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If he's got multiple AVMS, screwed-up blood flow would explain everything.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can only spot them with angiography. We'll have to do targeted scans with contrast and then embolize each one.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Can we do that before he freezes?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We'll find out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The spell-correct on Kutner’s phone has got a hair trigger. Either that, or the patient has a “cyclone in the floral of his lungs.” You took a walk in 45-degree weather, and you left your coat behind.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Go ahead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think you were punishing yourself. I think you wanted to feel what it would be like be homeless in a New Jersey winter. That tells me, guilt. That tells me, something happened.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The schizophrenia started when he was a teenager. When he was in college… He was on meds, but he'd still think a professor was out to get him because he got a B, or he'd fight with his roommates because he never showered.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where were you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Med school. He, called me, every day. Talked for hours. I didn't have hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Interesting. Later for that. Go on.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I was tired of being the guy that everybody counted on, so one night, Danny called — One night, Danny called, crying, upset about something. I had to study for an exam. So I — I hung up… Took my things. I went to the library so I wouldn't have to hear the phone ring.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I wonder how that turned out?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: My mother called me the next day. Danny had run away and left his meds behind. Which I knew meant that he would never be able to choose to come back, because he'd be so detached from reality.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So you made your one effort to live a normal, selfish life, and the universe immediately smacked you down. And because we're wired to find meaning in semi-random events, you decided never to be that careless again.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You don't think that's a little facile?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, I don't. I think you did it consciously. You developed your people-pleasing talents the way an Olympic athlete develops his muscles. Talk about an overreaction to a single event.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It was a pretty big event.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hanging up the phone? That's what you're blaming all this on. That's the behavior you've been trying to correct. As though nothing else went wrong in your brother's life. Of course, he overreacted too but… His glucose was normal?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We're not talking about my brother anymore, are we?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's House. AVMs don't explain his glucose.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Since this is a significant moment in my life and all, I…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think I'll just go in then.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Explain that.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You'd given him steroids. His glucose should have been elevated. That wannabe cyst you found in the whole body scan; without the glucose, it's an irrelevant cyst. With the glucose, it's a relevant fibroma. He has Doege-Potter syndrome.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: His fibroma is secreting human growth hormone, which acts like insulin, lowering his glucose.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It doesn't explain the organ failure or the brain damage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This whole thing is an overreaction. That one small fibroma. It's benign, but his body's acting like it's an invader. His antibodies went to war against it and got carried away, attacked his other systems. Take out the fibroma, he'll be a happy hypocrite again in no time.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Maybe I should call a cab.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Your wife's probably just late.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Yeah. I'm sorry about… You know… the things I said.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I have a conspicuous nose.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: It suits your face.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: I'm sorry I'm late. Traffic. I have some good news. I was gonna tell you, and then you got sick. It didn't seem like the best time. I've been offered a better position. I'd be coordinating cancer awareness walks in three cities.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: That's great. Congratulations! I know you've worked hard for this.

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Nick
utterance.content: Is Marika okay?

utterance.speaker: Audrey
utterance.content: I'm sure she's moved on. Kids are so resilient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You okay?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'll be seeing Danny again next week. I'd like you to meet him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure. He sounds interesting. Go on.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I thought seeing him again would change everything. It would be wonderful or terrible. Instead… we're just strangers. It's kind of, anticlimactic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which is better than terrible.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Go on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does it bother you that we have no social contract?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: My whole life is one big compromise. I tiptoe around everyone like they're made of china. I spend all my time analyzing: What will the effect be if I say this? Then there's you. You're a reality junkie. If I offered you a comforting lie, you'd smack me over the head with it. Let's not change that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, see, this — if you were implementing the social contract, you'd say that, but only because… It makes me feel better…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It is kind of fun watching you torture yourself.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Do you think things will work out with my brother?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. But when it does go wrong, it won't be your fault.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Thanks, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You do actually like monster trucks?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Absolutely.
